container.heading: Second-Hand Property, Antiques, and Consignment Goods

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this subtitle, the following words have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: Antique dealer.
para.text: "Antique dealer" means any person engaged in the business of buying for resale, trade, or transfer personal property that has special value because of its age, including but not limited to paintings, clothing, furniture, glass, ceramics, rugs, silverware, carvings, sculpture, and other moveable personal property, excluding motor vehicles, records, tapes, compact discs, and books.
"Consignment goods dealer" means any person receiving consignment goods for the purpose of selling them.
"Consignment goods" includes all categories of moveable personal property enumerated in subsections (b) and (f) of this section.

para.heading: Dealer.
para.text: "Dealer" means any:
second-hand personal property dealer;
antique dealer; or
consignment goods dealer.

para.heading: Second-hand personal property dealer.
para.text: "Second-hand personal property dealer" means any person engaged in the business of buying for resale, trade, or transfer used or previously owned property or merchandise, including, but not limited to, clothes, furniture, household items, and other moveable personal property, excluding motor vehicles, records, tapes, compact discs, and books.

para.heading: Transfer.
para.text: "Transfer" means to purchase, sell, trade, consign, or otherwise exchange personal property or merchandise for consideration.

para.heading: Pawnbrokers; scrap metal dealers.
para.text: This subtitle does not apply to:
any person licensed as a pawnbroker under Subtitle 11 of this article; or
any person licensed as a scrap metal dealer under Subtitle 8 of this article.

para.heading: Certain tax-exempt entities.
para.text: This subtitle does not apply to any dealer that is exempt from taxation under § 501(c)(3) or § 501(c)(4) of the Internal Revenue Code.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Except as provided in § 12-4 of this subtitle, each person conducting business as a second-hand personal property dealer, antique dealer, or consignment goods dealer within the City of Baltimore shall pay for the privilege of conducting that business by first taking out an annual license and paying an annual license fee in the amount of $50 for each place of business.

para.heading: Director of Consumer Protection and Business Licensing to issue.
para.text: The license shall be issued by the Director of the Department of Consumer Protection and Business Licensing.

para.heading: Fee collection.
para.text: The annual license fee shall be collectible pursuant to Article 15, Subtitles 46 and 47 of this Code.

para.heading: "Cooperative" defined.
para.text: In this section, "cooperative" means:
a facility that is owned and operated for the benefit of, and that provides space, clerical services, or other support services at a single location for, 2 or more dealers; or
any group of contiguous stores or outlets that are owned and operated as a single establishment.

para.heading: Master license authorized.
para.text: Subject to the rules and regulations of the Police Commissioner and the Department of Consumer Protection and Business Licensing, including provision for identifying member dealers as they change from time to time, the owner or operator of a cooperative may obtain 1 master license to cover all member dealers in the cooperative.

This master license fulfills the license requirements for all dealers who have been identified to the Police Commissioner and the Department of Consumer Protection and Business Licensingas members of the cooperative.
Member dealers remain individually responsible, however, for all reporting, identification, record keeping, retention, and other requirements of this subtitle.
The owner or operator who obtains the master license is not personally liable for any act or omission of a member dealer to which the owner or operator was not a party.

section.heading: Transactions with minors prohibited.
section.text: A dealer may not acquire any item in a transaction with a minor.

section.heading: Transferor to provide true name, etc.
section.text: An individual who transfers or otherwise disposes of an item to a dealer or to the agent or employee of a dealer may not fail or refuse to give:

para.text: the individual's true name, age, and address; and
if the individual is acting as an agent for a principal, the principal's true name, age, and address.

Each dealer shall submit to the Police Commissioner and the Director of Consumer Protection and Business Licensing a daily report of each transaction in which a person transfers items to the dealer on that day.
The dealer shall forward the daily report to the Police Department and Department of Consumer Protection and Business Licensing, as provided in § 12-8 of this subtitle.

para.heading: Scope of reports.
para.text: Except as provided in this subtitle, the daily report shall contain the information specified in subsection (c) of this section for:
each item transferred; or
each group of substantially similar items transferred as part of 1 transaction.

para.heading: Information required.
para.text: The daily report shall include:
the date, place, and time of each transaction, including the location where the dealer purchased or received the item or group of items;
a description of the item or group of items, including:
the specific type and number of items;
the manufacturer, model number, and year of manufacture, if known, and any soundex number or unique identifying number found on the item;
the color, size, style, and approximate age;

for jewelry (other than costume jewelry meeting standards set by the Police Commissioner), a description by weight (if payment is based on weight), style, gender, number and configuration of stones, and any initials or distinguishing marks or inscriptions;
a statement of whether or not the item appears to have been altered by any means, including:
obscuring a serial number or identifying feature;
melting; or
recutting a gem; and
the amount paid or other consideration;
for each individual from whom the dealer acquires an item:
the individual's name, date of birth, and license number from a clearly identifiable driver's license;
identification information about the individual that:

positively identifies the individual from at least 2 forms of identification, which may include an age of majority card, military identification, passport, or other similar photographic identification; and
provides a physical description of the individual, including the sex, race, date of birth, any distinguishing features, and weight of the individual; or
a statement by the dealer that:
the dealer has known the transferor of the item for 10 years or longer and knows that the transferor has lived at his/her current residence for not less than 3 years;
that the specific information required by subitems (i) or (ii) of this item (3) is retained in the dealer's records; and
that a record of the transaction signed by the individual from whom the item is acquired is retained in the dealer's records;

if the individual from whom the dealer acquires the item is acting as an agent for a principal, the same information for the principal as that which is required by item (3) of this subsection to be given for the agent;
a statement indicating whether or not the person making the transfer is personally known to the dealer; and
the signature of the dealer who accepted the item and, except for a transaction reported under item (3)(iii) of this subsection, the signature of the individual from whom the item is acquired.

para.heading: How.
para.text: A dealer shall submit each daily report to the Police Department and the Department of Consumer Protection and Business Licensingin the following formats:
by electronic transmittal, in the format and manner required by the Police Commissioner; and
if the electronic transmission is not submitted with an electronic signature acceptable to the Police Commissioner, in writing, on the forms supplied by the Police Commissioner.
The electronic report shall be submitted before noon on the business day immediately following the day for which the report is made.
The written report shall be submitted by:
mailing the report at the end of the business day for which the report is made; or
hand delivery or facsimile transmission before noon on the business day immediately following the day for which the report is made.

para.heading: Reports confidential.
para.text: A daily report submitted under this subtitle is confidential, as provided in § 12-304(c) of the Business Regulation Article of the Maryland Code.

para.heading: Required holding periods.
para.text: Except as authorized under subsection (b) of this section, each dealer shall hold at the dealer's place of business all acquired items, as follows:

a precious metal object, as defined in § 12-101 of the Business Regulation Article of the Maryland Code, shall be held for at least 18 days after the report of its acquisition is made in accordance with this subtitle; and
every other item shall be held for at least 10 days after the report of its acquisition is made in accordance with this subtitle.

The Police Commissioner shall adopt reasonable procedures for granting waivers or permitting shorter holding periods, on an ad hoc or long-term basis, in cases of dealer hardship, subject to such record-keeping or other reasonable requirements as may be necessary to preserve the integrity of the reporting and holding requirements of this subtitle.
These procedures shall include:
provisions for waiving the holding period for items purchased directly from, and previously held for the required period by, another dealer, pawnbroker, or scrap metal dealer; and
a mechanism for assuring prompt decisions on requests for waivers.
After the initial holding period required by subsection (a) of this section, a dealer shall continue to hold an item if:
a law enforcement officer requests that the dealer hold the item;
the law enforcement officer has reasonable cause to believe the item has been stolen; and
the item has not been identified under § 12-10(a)(2) of this subtitle.
If an item is placed on additional police hold under this subsection, the dealer shall:
continue to hold the item until:
the police seize it;
the Police Department releases the police hold or directs the item to be released to its owner; or
1 year after the additional police hold was imposed; and

if requested to do so, submit to the Police Department a photograph of the item, either by electronic transmittal or by mail or hand delivery, by the same deadline as required by § 12-8 of this subtitle for a daily report.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: A dealer shall release to the Police Department any item in the dealer's possession if:
the item is established to be stolen;
the owner of the item or the victim of the theft has:
positively identified the item; and
provided an affidavit of ownership or previously made a report of the theft to a law enforcement agency;
the stolen property report describes the item by:
date;
initials;
an insurance record;
a photograph;
a sales receipt;
a serial number;
specific damage;
a statement of facts that show the item is one of a kind; or
a unique engraving; and
the dealer is given a receipt for the item released.

para.heading: Return to owner.
para.text: When the police no longer need an item for evidence, it shall be returned to the owner.

para.heading: Reimbursement not prerequisite to release.
para.text: A dealer who is required to release an item under this section is not entitled to demand, or to condition the release on, any reimbursement from:
the Police Department;
the owner of the item; or
the victim of the theft.

section.heading: Labels.
section.text: All items in the dealer's place of business shall be clearly marked or labeled to correlate with:

para.text: the dealer's record of the transaction; and
the purchase receipt or, if the item is in for consignment or repair, the invoice.

section.heading: Retention of records.
section.text: For at least 3 years after the date of a transfer, the dealer shall hold all records of the transaction:

para.text: at the dealer's place of business; or

if otherwise specifically required by the dealer's property insurer, at some other suitable location designated by the dealer and from which the dealer can produce the records as and when needed by the Police Department and the Department of Consumer Protection and Business Licensing.

para.heading: Dealer to allow inspection.
para.text: A dealer shall allow a law enforcement officer or special enforcement officer, as defined in City Code Article 19, § 71-1 {"Appointment; duties"}, acting in the line of duty, to:
enter the dealer's place of business or storage premises during business hours; and
inspect any record of transactions subject to this subtitle and any items on the premises.

para.heading: Dealer's presence required.
para.text: On request of the dealer, the officer shall make the inspection in the presence of the dealer.

para.heading: Search warrant.
para.text: If the dealer refuses to allow access or refuses to produce a record or item for inspection, the officer shall seek a search warrant.

section.heading: Exemptions from reporting and holding requirements.

para.heading: Consignment goods.
para.text: Consignment goods are not subject to the daily reporting requirements of § 12-7 of this subtitle or to the item retention requirements of § 12-9 of this subtitle, as long as the dealer:
keeps a record, subject to inspection under § 12-13 of this subtitle, of all the information required by § 12-7 of this subtitle; and
complies with all other requirements of this subtitle.
This subsection applies to items acquired by a dealer:
from another licensed dealer;
from a person licensed as a pawnbroker;
from a person licensed as a scrap metal dealer;
at a public auction conducted by a licensed auctioneer;
from the personal representative of a decedent; or
at a public sale commonly known as a lawn sale, garage sale, or flea market.

Items acquired under paragraph (1) of this subsection are not subject to the daily reporting requirements of § 12-7 of this subtitle or to the item retention requirements of § 12-9 of this subtitle, as long as the acquiring dealer:
keeps a record, subject to inspection under § 12-13 of this subtitle, of the information required by § 12-7 of this subtitle; and
complies with all other requirements of this subtitle.

para.heading: Flea market dealers.
para.text: Second-hand personal property acquired by a dealer for resale, trade, or transfer exclusively at a flea market is not subject to the daily reporting requirements of § 12-7 of this subtitle or to the item retention requirements of § 12-9 of this subtitle, as long as:
all of the dealer's resale, trade, or transfer business is conducted exclusively at the flea market;
the flea market is open for business no more than 2 days a week;
either:
the dealer is licensed under this subtitle; or
the flea market has obtained a master license as a cooperative and the dealer is identified as a member of that cooperative; and
the dealer keeps a record, subject to inspection under § 12-13 of this subtitle, of all the information required by § 12-7 of this subtitle.

section.heading: Rules and regulations.
section.text: Subject to Title 4 {"Administrative Procedure Act – Regulations"} of the City General Provisions Article, the Police Commissioner, in consultation with the Director of Consumer Protection and Business Licensing may adopt rules and regulations to implement this subtitle and shall make these rules and regulations available to dealers and the general public.

annotations.annotation: By authority of Ordinance 20-431, Section 5, the Director of Legislative Reference, in consultation with the Law Department, has conformed the text of this section to refer expressly to the requirements of the recently-enacted Administrative Procedure Act that, effective January 15, 2021, governs the proposal, adoption, and publication of administrative rules and regulations.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Any person who violates any provision of this subtitle or of a published rule or regulation adopted under this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine of not less than $500 nor more than $1,000 or to imprisonment for 6 months or to both fine and imprisonment in the discretion of the Court.

para.heading: Forfeit of noncomplying item.
para.text: In addition, a person convicted of violating this subtitle may be required to forfeit any item found not in compliance with this subtitle.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this subtitle, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: Automated purchasing machine; APM.
para.text: "Automated purchasing machine" or "APM" (also known as a "reverse vending machine") means a self-service automated device that, without the physical presence of a human agent, is capable of taking possession of and dispensing payment for any 1 or more types of personal property.

section.heading: General prohibition.
section.text: Except as otherwise expressly provided in this subtitle, no person may purchase or offer to purchase any personal property by means of an automated purchasing machine.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: This subtitle does not prohibit the use of an automated purchasing machine exclusively for collecting recyclable materials pursuant to a recycling program approved jointly by the Police Commissioner and the Commission on Sustainability.

para.heading: Rules and Regulations.
para.text: Subject to Title 4 {"Administrative Procedure Act – Regulations"} of the City General Provisions Article, the Police Commissioner and the Commission on Sustainability may jointly adopt rules, regulations, and standards governing the recyclable materials and recycling programs that may be approved for purposes of this exception.

annotations.annotation: By authority of Ordinance 20-431, Section 5, the Director of Legislative Reference, in consultation with the Law Department, has conformed the text of subsection (b) to refer expressly to the requirements of the recently-enacted Administrative Procedure Act that, effective January 15, 2021, governs the proposal, adoption, and publication of administrative rules and regulations.

section.heading: In general.
section.text: An automated purchasing machine ("APM") is subject to seizure and forfeiture if it is used in violation of this subtitle.

para.heading: When warrant not needed.
para.text: A police officer need not have a warrant to seize an APM if:
the police officer has probable cause to believe the APM has been used in violation of this subtitle; and
a warrant is not constitutionally required under the circumstances.

para.heading: Removal of APM.
para.text: Whenever a police officer seizes an APM under this subtitle, the police officer may cause it to be moved to a place designated by the Police Commissioner.

para.heading: APM not repleviable.
para.text: An APM seized under this subtitle is not repleviable and remains in the custody of the Police Department, subject only to the orders and decrees of the court or official with jurisdiction over it.

para.heading: Police to refer case.
para.text: Promptly after seizure, the Police Department shall notify the City Solicitor in writing of the facts and circumstances supporting the seizure.
On receiving the report, the Solicitor shall conduct an independent review of the facts and circumstances surrounding the seizure.

If the Solicitor finds sufficient evidence that the APM was used in violation of this subtitle, the Solicitor shall notify the APM's owner, by registered or certified mail, of the seizure and of the City's intent to institute forfeiture proceedings.
If, on the other hand, the Solicitor finds that there is insufficient evidence to prove violation, the Solicitor shall surrender the APM to the owner on the owner's request.

para.heading: Filing; copies to parties in interest.
para.text: If the Solicitor determines that the APM should be forfeited, the Solicitor shall, within 90 days after the seizure of the APM:

file a forfeiture petition in a court of competent jurisdiction, in the name of the City against the APM, as designated by the APM's type, manufacturer, model number or name, color, size, and serial number; and
at the same time, send copies of the petition by registered or certified mail to the APM's owner and any known secured party.

para.heading: Contents.
para.text: The petition for forfeiture shall contain:
the name of the APM's owner;
the name of any secured party whose interest appears among the records maintained by the Clerk of the Circuit Court for Baltimore City;
a statement of the facts and circumstances surrounding the seizure of the APM;
a statement of the specific grounds for forfeiture; and
a request that the APM be forfeited to the City.
Within 7 days of the petition's filing, the Solicitor shall publish notice of the seizure and forfeiture proceeding in 1 or more newspapers of general circulation in the City.
The notice shall:
state the substance and object of the forfeiture petition; and
state that any person claiming an interest in the seized APM must file a defense to the petition within 15 days of the date of the notice.

para.heading: When to be made.
para.text: Any defense to the petition must be filed within 15 days after publication of the notice.
All defenses to a petition for forfeiture must be made by answer.
The answer must:
comply with the Maryland Rules of Procedure as to form and contents;
be divided into numbered paragraphs, each containing a separate and distinctive averment; and

respond to each material allegation contained in the petition, specifically admitting, denying, or explaining the facts alleged, unless the respondent is without knowledge or an admission or explanation would tend to incriminate the respondent, in either of which events the respondent must so state and that statement will operate as a denial.
Every allegation in the petition that is not denied in the answer is considered admitted, except as to persons unknown.
New or affirmative matter alleged in the answer is considered denied or avoided by the petitioner without the need of any replication, unless the court orders otherwise.
If the court determines that the APM should be forfeited, the court shall order the APM forfeited to the City.

If, however, the court determines that the APM is subject to a bona fide recorded security interest created without the knowledge that the APM was being or was to be used in violation of this subtitle, the court shall order that the APM be released within 5 days to the secured party of record.

para.heading: Disposition of APM subject to security interest.

para.text: The secured party:
shall sell the APM in a commercially reasonable manner; and
may not sell the APM to the owner or other person from whom it was seized.
The proceeds of the sale shall be applied as follows:
to the court costs of the forfeiture proceedings;
to the balance due to the secured party, including all reasonable costs incident to the sale;
to payment of all other expenses of the proceedings for forfeiture, including expenses of seizure, maintenance, or custody; and
to the general funds of the City.

section.heading: Order of release.
section.text: If, after a full hearing, the court determines that the APM should not be forfeited, the court shall order the APM released.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: A person who violates any provision of this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, subject to a fine of not more than $500 or imprisonment for not more than 6 months or both fine and imprisonment for each offense.

para.heading: Each transaction a separate offense.
para.text: Each transaction in violation of this subtitle is a separate offense.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: This subtitle shall apply to real estate brokers, real estate salesmen, and real estate dealers as herein defined.

para.heading: Real estate.
para.text: "Real estate" shall include leaseholds and all other interests in real property.

para.heading: Real estate broker.
para.text: "Real estate broker" shall mean any person, association, copartnership, or corporation, foreign or domestic, who:
for another and for a fee, commission, or any other valuable consideration, sells, purchases, exchanges, leases, rents, or collects rent, for the use of real estate;
attempts or who offers by verbal solicitation, advertisement, or otherwise to perform any such function; or
is engaged in the business of subdividing and selling land in building lots or sites.

para.heading: Real estate dealer.
para.text: "Real estate dealer" shall mean one who is regularly engaged in the business of dealing and trading in real estate or leases and options thereof.

para.heading: Real estate salesman.
para.text: "Real estate salesman" shall mean any person who performs on behalf of any real estate broker, any act or acts authorized by the Maryland Real Estate Brokers Act to be performed by a real estate broker.

section.heading: Scope of subtitle – Inclusions.
section.text: Any person, partnership, association, or corporation who, for another in consideration of compensation by fee, commission, salary, or otherwise or with the intention or in the expectation or upon the promise of receiving or collecting a fee, does, offers, or attempts or agrees to do, engages in or offers or attempts or agrees to engage in, either directly or indirectly, any single act or transaction contained in the definition of "real estate broker" or "real estate salesman" in this subtitle, whether said act be an incidental part of a transaction or the entire transaction, shall be deemed a real estate broker or real estate salesman within the meaning of this subtitle.

section.heading: Scope of subtitle – Exclusions.
section.text: Notwithstanding the foregoing definitions, the terms "real estate broker" and "real estate salesman" shall not include:

para.text: receivers, trustees, administrators, executors, guardians, or other persons appointed by or acting under the judgment of or order of any court;
public officers while performing their official duties as such;

any bank, trust company, or mortgage loan institution organized under the laws of this State or the United States with respect to the management or sale of any property acquired through or in connection with mortgage foreclosures;
investment homebuilders with respect to the sale or rental of housing constructed by them;

attorneys-at-law who are not regularly engaged in the real estate business and who do not hold themselves out by sign, advertisement, or otherwise as offering to the general public the services authorized to be performed by real estate brokers and pursuant to the Maryland Real Estate Brokers Act;

any person holding in good faith a duly executed power of attorney from the actual owner authorizing the sale and conveyance or leasing of any real estate where only 1 such transaction is involved; or
any duly licensed auctioneer with respect to sale of real estate at public auction.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: No real estate broker or salesman shall, or shall attempt to:

use any contract form for the listing of property for sale, rent, or exchange or any contract form for the sale, rent, or exchange of property or advertising matter which includes the name of any association or organization of which the broker or salesman is not a member;

retain the services of any person as a salesman on a purely temporary or single transaction basis as a means of evading the law regarding the payment of commissions to non-licensed persons on some contemplated transaction;
act for more than 1 party in a transaction without the prior knowledge and consent of all parties for whom he acts;
refuse or fail within 30 days after demand to account for or to remit any monies coming into his possession which belong to others;

refuse or fail to promptly furnish a duplicate copy of all listing contracts to sell or rent property or of any lease or contract or sale when prepared by a real estate broker to all parties to any such contracts or leases;
fail to retain a copy of such contracts;

fail to disclose to any person with whom the broker or salesman is dealing any material fact or information within the knowledge of the broker or salesman concerning or relating to the property with which the broker or salesman is dealing;
make any untrue or misleading statement in any attempt to obtain a listing of real property for sale:
knowing such statement to be false or misleading; or
knowing that the broker or salesman making the statement has insufficient knowledge of its truth or falsity to warrant making the statement;
accept a listing contract to sell property unless such contract provides for a definite termination date without notice from either party;
accept any listing contract which provides for a net return to the vendor leaving the broker or salesman free to sell property and retain any excess over the price named by the vendor;
pay or receive any rebate, compensation, or commission from any person whatever, except the seller of the real estate, without the prior knowledge and consent of all parties to the transaction;
disregard or violate any of the provisions of the Maryland Real Estate Brokers Act; or

have any interest, directly or indirectly, in the purchase of any residential real estate which he or his organization has listed for sale, where such purchase is made during or within 6 months after the termination of such listing.

para.heading: Exceptions to prohibited interest in purchase.

para.text: Provided, however, that subsection (a)(13) shall not apply in cases in which a broker enters into a listing contract and a simultaneous "trade-in" agreement, whereby the broker or any company, partnership, or corporation in which the broker has any interest, either directly or indirectly, offers a guaranteed price for the listed property within a certain period in order for the seller to purchase another residence, either new or existing housing.
Provided, further, that subsection (a)(13) shall not apply in cases in which:

the broker or salesman discloses to the seller, in writing, at the time an offer or contract of sale is presented, any interest, direct or indirect, that the broker or salesman has in such offer to purchase the residential real estate which the broker or salesman or his organization has listed for sale; and
the terms of the offer or contract of sale permit the seller to withdraw from same if:

the appraised value of the property, as determined within 21 days of the offer or contract of sale by an appraiser who is a member of an appraisal organization affiliated with the Appraisal Foundation or is certified by the Maryland Commission of Real Estate Appraisers as a residential real estate appraiser, is higher than the purchase price as contained in the offer or contract of sale; and
the broker or salesperson declines to amend the purchase price in the offer or contract of sale to equal said appraised value.
Nothing in this subsection shall prevent a seller from waiving the rights provided for in this subsection in a contract of sale.

para.heading: Clarification.
para.text: Nothing in this section shall be construed to authorize any such broker or salesman personally to prepare any such legal paper in his practice.

section.heading: Prohibited conduct – Brokers, salespersons, and dealers.
section.text: In transactions involving residential real or leasehold properties, no real estate broker, salesman, or dealer shall or shall attempt to:

para.text: pursue a continued flagrant course of misrepresentation or make any false promises directly or through agents, salesmen, advertising, or otherwise;
make any misleading or untrue statements in advertising residential real or leasehold property including:
advertising for sale or rent as an agent or broker without disclosing in such advertising the name of the advertiser or the fact that he is an agent or broker; or

where any such advertising is published over the name of a licensed real estate salesman, failing to disclose in such advertising the name of the broker for whom such salesman is licensed to represent;

solicit or induce any party to a contract lease or agreement to break such contract for the purpose of substituting a new contract lease or agreement when such soliciting or inducing is motivated by anticipated personal gain;
guarantee or authorize or permit any person to guarantee future profits which may result from the resale of residential real or leasehold property;
solicit or offer for sale residential real or leasehold property by:
offering "free lots", conducting lotteries or contests, or offering prizes for the purpose of influencing a purchase or prospective purchaser of residential real or leasehold property; or

advertising or offering "free appraisals" unless the advertiser is equipped and stands ready to appraise real estate to any person requesting such an appraisal free of charge, regardless of the purpose for which such appraisal is requested;
make any untrue or misleading statements to induce the sale of residential real or leasehold property, whether to the person making the representation or to any other person:
knowing such statements to be false or misleading; or
knowing that the maker of the statement has insufficient knowledge of its truth or falsity to warrant making the statement;
if one of the purposes of the solicitation or attempted solicitation would be to change the racial composition of a neighborhood, solicit the listing of residential properties for sale or lease by:
in person, door-to-door solicitation;
telephone solicitation; or
mass distribution of circulars;

whether or not acting for monetary gain, knowingly induce another person to sell or rent a dwelling or otherwise transfer real estate or knowingly discourage another person from buying real estate by:

making representations about the entry or prospective entry into a neighborhood of individuals of a particular race, color, sex, religion, ancestry, sexual orientation, physical or mental disability, familial status, or national origin;

making representations about the existing or potential proximity of real property owned or used by individuals of a particular race, color, sex, religion, ancestry, sexual orientation, physical or mental disability, familial status, or national origin; or

representing that the existing or potential proximity of real property owned or used by individuals of a particular race, color, sex, religion, ancestry, sexual orientation, physical or mental disability familial status, or national origin will or may result in:
the lowering of property values;
a change in the racial, religious, or ethnic character of the block, neighborhood, or area;
an increase in criminal or antisocial behavior in the area; or
a decline in the quality of schools serving the area; or

provide financial assistance by loan, gift, or otherwise to another person if the real estate broker, salesman, or dealer has actual knowledge that the financial assistance will be used in a transaction that results from a violation of item (8) of this section.

section.heading: Prohibited conduct – Salespersons.
section.text: No real estate salesman shall:

para.text: accept a commission or valuable consideration as a real estate salesman for the performance of any act as a real estate salesman from any person except the real estate broker named in his license; or
represent or attempt to represent any other real estate broker as a real estate salesman without the knowledge and consent of the broker named in his license.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: A violation of the provisions of this subtitle shall be a misdemeanor and any person convicted thereof shall be subject to a fine of $100 and not more than $500 or to imprisonment of not more than 60 days or to both such fine and imprisonment at the discretion of the court.
Where an offense is committed by 1 or more individuals acting for a corporation, it shall be deemed to be the offense of both the corporation and the individual.
Where the offense is committed by 1 or more individuals acting in behalf of a partnership or association, it shall be deemed to be:
the offense of the partnership or association and the individual; and
the personal offense of any partner or associate who aids, abets, directs, counsels, and/or knowingly participates therein.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this subtitle, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: Seller.
para.text: "Seller" means:
the owner of real property being offered for sale; or
a real estate agent, attorney, lender, or other person acting on behalf of the owner of the property being offered for sale.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: No person may advertise, through any medium, the sale or lease of any property that, under the Zoning Code of Baltimore City, is restricted in its use and occupancy to 1 family, without including in the advertisement a clear statement to that effect.

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: Any person who violates any provision of this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine of not more than $500 for each offense.

para.heading: Advertisements.
para.text: If a seller of real property provides property tax information as part of an advertisement, that information must indicate, at a minimum:
the tax year for which the information is being provided; and
the product of:
the sum of the State and local property tax rates, multiplied by
the full assessed value for the tax year indicated.

para.heading: Estimate of closing costs.
para.text: Property tax information to be provided as part of a good-faith estimate of closing costs must be based on the product of:
the sum of the State and local property tax rates, multiplied by
the full assessed value for the tax year immediately following the purchase date of the property.

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: Any person who violates any provision of this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine of not more than $1,000 for each offense.

section.heading: Heavy-industrial and railroad operations.
section.text: On or before entering into a contract for the sale of any real property, the seller must provide the buyer with the following disclosure:

text.strong: Disclosure of Heavy-Industrial and Railroad Operations

include.text: Buyer is advised that the property may be located near heavy-industrial operations (that is, land uses limited to an I-2 General Industrial Zoning District, an MI Maritime Industrial Zoning District, or a T Transportation Zoning District) or near railroad operations.
These operations may involve the use of machinery, trucks, or trains, 24 hours a day, 7 days a week, and may create or cause noises, odors, fumes, bright lights, vibrations, and safety hazards.

Detailed information on the location of heavy-industrial (I-2, MI, and T) zones and on the location of railroad tracks can be found on the "Baltimore CityView" website, at http://cityview.baltimorecity.gov.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: On or before entering into a contract for the sale of any real property, the seller must disclose to the buyer in writing whether the property is:

located in a Historical and Architectural Preservation District, as defined under Article 6, § 1-1(f) {"Definitions – Historical and Architectural Preservation District; Preservation District; District"} of the Code;
included on the Landmark List: Exteriors, as established by Article 6, Subtitle 4 {"Designation of Landmarks"} of the Code; or
included on the Potential-Landmark List: Exteriors, as established by Article 6, Subtitle 5 {"Designation of Potential Landmarks"} of the Code.

CHAP is responsible for promoting the preservation of structures located in a historic district, included on the Landmark List: Exteriors, or included on the Potential-Landmark List: Exteriors under Article 6 {"Historical and Architectural Preservation"} of the City Code. container.heading: Ticket Sales – Charges by Operators and Agents

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this subtitle, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: Authorized sales agent.
para.text: "Authorized sales agent" means a person that:
is engaged in the business of selling tickets for others; and
by written contract with an operator, has been authorized to sell tickets for and on behalf of that operator.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: "Box office price" means the price that:
has been established by the operator of an entertainment venue for admission to the venue or to a specified seat or area within the venue; and
is so identified on the face of the ticket.

para.heading: Inclusions.
para.text: "Box office price" includes the applicable State or City admissions and amusement tax only if the tax is determined by the operator on a "tax-included basis" authorized by the State Tax-General Article, § 4-102(f).

para.heading: Exclusions.
para.text: "Box office price" does not include:
any additional service or other charge or fee imposed by an operator, by an operator's authorized sales agent, or by any other person; or
except as specified in paragraph (2) of this subsection, any tax to be collected by an operator or the operator's authorized sales agent.

para.heading: Entertainment.
para.text: "Entertainment" includes any of the following, whether presented live, recorded, televised, or otherwise:
any theatrical, musical, sports, dance, movie, cultural, or educational event, performance, competition, or exhibition; and
any other form of diversion, recreation, or show.
"Entertainment venue" means any place in Baltimore City for which a charge is imposed for admission to any form of entertainment.
"Entertainment venue" includes:
any theater, hall, stage, arena, stadium, field, amusement park, circus, carnival, or fairgrounds; or
or any other place, including any area within a venue for which a separate charge is imposed.

para.heading: Gross ticket cost.
para.text: "Gross ticket cost" means the sum of:
the box office price;
all State and City taxes collected by the operator or the operator's authorized sales agent; and
all service or other charges or fees imposed on the ticket by the operator or the operator's authorized sales agent.

para.heading: Operator.
para.text: "Operator" means any person who:
owns, operates, or controls an entertainment venue in Baltimore City; or
promotes or produces entertainment in Baltimore City.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: "Person" has the meaning stated in § 1-107(a) {"Person: In general"} of the City Code's General Provisions Article.

para.heading: Qualified inclusion of governmental entities.
para.text: Notwithstanding § 1-107(b) {"Person: Exclusion"} of the General Provisions Article, in this subtitle "person" also includes, except for the application of § 16-11{"Prepayable citation"} and § 16-12 {"Criminal penalties"}, a governmental entity or an instrumentality or unit of a governmental entity.

para.heading: Sell.
para.text: "Sell" means to sell or exchange or offer to sell or exchange a ticket, whether:
in-person;
by mail or delivery service; or
by telephone, facsimile, email, internet website, or other electronic medium.

para.heading: Ticket.
para.text: "Ticket" means any ticket, card, token, receipt, or other evidence of the privilege of admission to any entertainment venue.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, nothing in this subtitle affects the applicability and enforceability of any other law, rule, or regulation, including those concerning consumer protection, licensing and regulation, fraudulent or misleading advertising, or theft.

para.heading: Conflicting provisions.
para.text: If any provision of this article is either more or less restrictive than a comparable condition imposed by any other law, rule, or regulation of any kind, the condition that is the more restrictive governs.

section.heading: Rules and regulations.
section.text: Subject to Title 4 {"Administrative Procedure Act – Regulations"} of the City General Provisions Article, the Director of Finance may adopt rules and regulations as necessary or appropriate to:

para.text: define or further define any terms used in this subtitle; and
otherwise promote the implementation and enforcement of this subtitle.

container.heading: Charges by Operators and their Agents

section.heading: In general.
section.text: An operator or an operator's authorized sales agent may not impose, accept, or receive, directly or indirectly, for any ticket more than the following:

para.text: the box office price;
any separately stated admissions and amusement tax; and
additional service or other charges or fees that have been identified and disclosed as required by this subtitle.

para.heading: On face of ticket.
para.text: Every ticket printed by or under authority of an operator or an operator's authorized sales agent must prominently disclose on its face the box office price of that ticket.

para.heading: Advertising and listings.
para.text: If a printed advertisement or listing prepared by or for an operator or an operator's authorized sales agent states the box office price of a ticket (or a range of tickets), and if the gross ticket price of the ticket (or range of tickets), as sold by the operator or the operator's authorized sales agent, exceeds the stated box office price (or range of prices), the advertisement or listing must, in the same or larger font as that used for the stated box office price (or range of prices), include the following statement: "Additional Charges May Apply".

para.heading: Itemization of charges and fees at point or time of sale.

para.text: This subsection does not apply if the gross ticket cost of the ticket, as sold by either the operator or the operator's authorized sales agent, does not exceed the box office price disclosed on the face of the ticket.

Every operator and its authorized sales agent must prominently post at its box office, sales outlet, or other point of sale (including a website or other electronic medium), an itemized list of the following, as applicable to each entertainment venue and each entertainment event at that venue for which tickets are being sold:
the box office price of the tickets; and
in the same or larger font as that used for the box office price:

the type and amount of each State and City tax that is applicable to the transaction and that has not been determined by the operator on a "tax-included basis" as authorized by the State Tax-General Article, § 4-102(f);
the type and amount of each service or other charge or fee imposed on the ticket by the operator and by the operator's authorized sales agent, respectively; and
the gross ticket cost of the ticket, as sold by the operator and as sold by the operator's authorized sales agent, respectively.
In addition:
immediately before finalization of any sale by an operator or its authorized sales agent:
the itemized list of costs described in paragraph (2) of this subsection must be disclosed to each potential purchaser; or
if the purchase is being finalized by telephone, the itemized list of costs described in paragraph (2) of this subsection must be read to the purchaser in a clear and distinct manner; and
immediately after finalization of any sale by an operator or its authorized sales agent:
the itemized list of costs described in paragraph (2) of this subsection must be given to each purchaser; or

the ticket provided to the purchaser must prominently disclose on its face both the amount of the box office price of the ticket and, in the same or larger font size, the amount of the gross price of the ticket.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In addition to any other civil or criminal remedy or enforcement procedure, this subtitle may be enforced by issuance of:
an environmental citation under City Code Article 1, Subtitle 40 {"Environmental Control Board"}; or
a civil citation under City Code Article 1, Subtitle 41 {"Civil Citations"}.

para.heading: Process not exclusive.
para.text: The issuance of a citation to enforce this subtitle does not preclude pursuing any other civil or criminal remedy or enforcement action authorized by law.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Any person who violates any provision of this subtitle or of a rule or regulation adopted under this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine of not more than $500 or imprisonment for not more than 90 days or both fine and imprisonment for each offense.

para.heading: Each ticket a separate offense.
para.text: Each ticket sold or exchanged or offered for sale or exchange in violation of this subtitle is a separate offense.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this subtitle, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: Entertainment.
para.text: "Entertainment" includes any of the following, whether presented live, recorded, televised, or otherwise:
any theatrical, musical, sports, dance, movie, cultural, or educational event, performance, competition, or exhibition; and
any other form of diversion, recreation, or show.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: "Entertainment venue" means any place in Baltimore City for which a charge is imposed for admission to any form of entertainment.

para.heading: Inclusions.
para.text: "Entertainment venue" includes:
any theater, hall, stage, arena, stadium, field, amusement park, circus, carnival, or fairgrounds; or
or any other place, including any area within a venue for which a separate charge is imposed.

para.heading: Operator.
para.text: "Operator" means any person who:
owns, operates, or controls an entertainment venue in Baltimore City; or
promotes or produces entertainment in Baltimore City.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: "Person" has the meaning stated in § 1-107(a) {"Person: In general"} of the City Code's General Provisions Article.

para.heading: Qualified inclusion of governmental entities.
para.text: Notwithstanding § 1-107(b) {"Person: Exclusion"} of the General Provisions Article, in this subtitle "person" also includes, except for the application of § 17-11{"Prepayable citation"} and § 17-12 {"Criminal penalties"} of this subtitle, a governmental entity or an instrumentality or unit of a governmental entity.

para.heading: Retail ticket purchasing platform.
para.text: "Retail ticket purchasing platform" means a retail ticket purchasing website, application, phone system, or other technology platform used to sell tickets.

para.heading: Ticket.
para.text: "Ticket" means any ticket, card, token, receipt, or other evidence of the privilege of admission to any entertainment venue.

para.heading: Ticket purchasing software.
para.text: "Ticket purchasing software" means any machine, device, computer program, or computer software that, on its own or with human assistance, bypasses security measures or access control systems on a retail ticket purchasing platform, or other controls or measures on a retail ticket purchasing platform that assist in implementing a limit on the number of tickets that can be purchased.

section.heading: Using ticket purchasing software.
section.text: No person may use ticket purchasing software to purchase tickets.

section.heading: Resale of tickets obtained by using ticket purchasing software.
section.text: No person may resell or offer to resell a ticket that the person knows was obtained by using ticket purchasing software.

section.heading: Maintaining interest in or control of ticket purchasing software.
section.text: No person may intentionally maintain any interest in or control of ticket purchasing software.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In addition to any other civil or criminal remedy or enforcement procedure, this subtitle may be enforced by issuance of:
an environmental citation under City Code Article 1, Subtitle 40 {"Environmental Control Board"}; or
a civil citation under City Code Article 1, Subtitle 41 {"Civil Citations"}.

para.heading: Process not exclusive.
para.text: The issuance of a citation to enforce this subtitle does not preclude pursuing any other civil or criminal remedy or enforcement action authorized by law.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Any person who violates any provision of this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to:
a fine of not more than $500 or imprisonment for not more than 90 days or both fine and imprisonment for each offense;
forfeiture of all profits from the sale of tickets obtained in violation of this subtitle; and
forfeiture of any equipment used to purchase tickets in violation of this subtitle.

para.heading: Each ticket a separate offense.
para.text: Each ticket purchased, resold, or offered for resale in violation of this subtitle is a separate offense.
